explanation:
The correct calculation shows \( 9^{0} = 1 \), as any non-zero base raised to the 0 power equals 1.  
The student likely computed \( 9 \times 0 = 0 \), treating the exponent as a multiplicative factor.  
This error stems from misinterpreting the exponential notation \( 9^{x} \) as requiring multiplication of the base by the exponent rather than repeated multiplication of the base.  
The misconception directly maps to confusing the operation \( a^{n} \) (which means \( a \times a \times \dots \times a \)) with \( a \times n \), specifically replacing the exponentiation with scalar multiplication.  
This differs from the related misconception of "writes a variable to the power of \( n \) as \( nx \)" because the error here involves a numerical base (9) rather than a variable, and specifically applies to the \( x=0 \) case.  
The error is not caused by symmetry assumptions or zero-product properties, as those would manifest differently in other positions of the table.
